articles.headline: You Can’t Fire Equifax, but Your Employer Can. Mine Just Did.
articles.snippet: After Equifax’s security breach, consumers looked for ways to make the company pay. One option: Persuade employers not to give the company any data.
articles.abstract: After Equifax’s security breach, consumers looked for ways to make the company pay. One option: Persuade employers not to give the company any data.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the Equifax data breach in early September, readers asked one question repeatedly that had no good answer: Was there any way to punish the company?

articles.headline: Trump Arrived in Davos as a Party Wrecker. He Leaves Praised as a Pragmatist.
articles.snippet: President Trump used two days in Davos to assuage the worst fears about his presidency among the global elite while aggressively courting investment.
articles.abstract: President Trump used two days in Davos to assuage the worst fears about his presidency among the global elite while aggressively courting investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — No one was declaring President Trump a changed man. Privately, executives and global leaders who had gathered in Davos continued to worry that the American president could yet indulge his worst instincts — and his penchant for shock on Twitter — to deliver a geopolitical crisis, open up a new front in trade hostilities or offend a vast group of people.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Grounded and Gutted, Main Afghan Airline Struggles After Taliban Attack
articles.snippet: With insurgents threatening road travel, Kam Air has kept Afghanistan moving. But its future looks grim with foreign crew members dead or fleeing.
articles.abstract: With insurgents threatening road travel, Kam Air has kept Afghanistan moving. But its future looks grim with foreign crew members dead or fleeing.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Its pilots land in cities terrorized by the Taliban, the tarmacs within easy reach of rocket fire.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Fahim Abed

articles.headline: Promising Billions to Amazon: Is It a Good Deal for Cities?
articles.snippet: Many economists see deals offering tax breaks to attract corporate sites as inefficient, expensive and ultimately ineffective.
articles.abstract: Many economists see deals offering tax breaks to attract corporate sites as inefficient, expensive and ultimately ineffective.
articles.lead_paragraph: When New Jersey announced a $7 billion package of tax incentives to try to lure Amazon’s second headquarters to Newark, local officials saw a chance to jump-start a city that has long struggled with poverty and joblessness.

articles.headline: The U.S. May Back a Vietnam Coal Plant. Russia Is Already Helping.
articles.snippet: A state-run company in Vietnam is seeking support from the Export-Import Bank for a project that could benefit American business but is criticized by environmentalists.
articles.abstract: A state-run company in Vietnam is seeking support from the Export-Import Bank for a project that could benefit American business but is criticized by environmentalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONG PHU, Vietnam — The towering lattice of blue steel girders rising above banana and lemongrass crops near Vietnam’s southern coast stands as public testament to the country’s drive to burn coal.

articles.headline: Stephen Wynn, Casino Mogul, Accused of Decades of Sexual Misconduct
articles.snippet: A report outlining years of sexual misconduct by Mr. Wynn sent shares in his company, Wynn Resorts, plummeting and raised questions about his future in Republican politics.
articles.abstract: A report outlining years of sexual misconduct by Mr. Wynn sent shares in his company, Wynn Resorts, plummeting and raised questions about his future in Republican politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen Wynn’s perch at the top of the casino industry was badly shaken on Friday following the disclosure of allegations that he engaged in a long pattern of sexual misconduct with employees of his casinos.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Tiffany Hsu and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Counsel Quietly Trying to Corral Trump While Pushing G.O.P.’s Agenda
articles.snippet: As a series of firings and resignations roiled the first year of the Trump administration, Donald F. McGahn II maintained a low profile, but he has recently been thrust squarely into the public eye.
articles.abstract: As a series of firings and resignations roiled the first year of the Trump administration, Donald F. McGahn II maintained a low profile, but he has recently been thrust squarely into the public eye.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald F. McGahn II, the White House counsel, moved into his corner office on the West Wing’s second floor last January, he chose not to decorate its walls or fill its glass-paneled shelving with personal items. He told colleagues that he travels light because he never knows when he might be asked to leave.

articles.headline: ‘It’s a Massacre’: Blast in Kabul Deepens Toll of a Long War
articles.snippet: At least 95 were killed and 158 others were wounded when a car bomber drove an ambulance past two checkpoints and detonated explosives.
articles.abstract: At least 95 were killed and 158 others were wounded when a car bomber drove an ambulance past two checkpoints and detonated explosives.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban drove an ambulance packed with explosives into a crowded Kabul street on Saturday, setting off an enormous blast that killed at least 95 people and injured 158 others, adding to the grim toll in what has been one of the most violent stretches of the long war, Afghan officials said.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Jawad Sukhanyar

articles.headline: Every One of the World’s Big Economies Is Now Growing
articles.snippet: For the first time since the global economic downturn, there is a wave of expansion that is creating jobs, lifting fortunes and tempering fears of popular discontent.
articles.abstract: For the first time since the global economic downturn, there is a wave of expansion that is creating jobs, lifting fortunes and tempering fears of popular discontent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A decade after the world descended into a devastating economic crisis, a key marker of revival has finally been achieved. Every major economy on earth is expanding at once, a synchronous wave of growth that is creating jobs, lifting fortunes and tempering fears of popular discontent.

articles.headline: Reese Witherspoon’s Second Act: Big-Time Producer
articles.snippet: From Oscar-winning actress to Emmy-winning producer: After taking charge of her career, she makes deals with HBO and Apple.
articles.abstract: From Oscar-winning actress to Emmy-winning producer: After taking charge of her career, she makes deals with HBO and Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Reese Witherspoon realized everything had changed.

articles.headline: The Mind Meld of Bill Gates and Steven Pinker
articles.snippet: The entrepreneur-turned-philanthropist and the best-selling author discuss their surprising bond, the challenge to improve the human condition and the quest to create the perfect toilet.
articles.abstract: The entrepreneur-turned-philanthropist and the best-selling author discuss their surprising bond, the challenge to improve the human condition and the quest to create the perfect toilet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first two things you notice when you walk into Bill Gates’s private office, just outside Seattle, are a wall-size installation of the periodic table with a sample of each chemical element in its own glass-fronted vitrine and handsome bookshelves that reach nearly to the ceiling.

articles.headline: Billionaire Saudi Prince, Alwaleed bin Talal, Is Freed From Detention
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s most prominent investor, he had been detained in the Ritz-Carlton in the capital after a mass crackdown on corruption.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s most prominent investor, he had been detained in the Ritz-Carlton in the capital after a mass crackdown on corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For more than 80 days, he was locked up, incommunicado, in the capital of the kingdom named after his family as alarm spread among his relatives and business partners.

articles.headline: As Gridlock Deepens in Congress, Only Gloom Is Bipartisan
articles.snippet: Republicans warn of a dark plot to overthrow the Trump government and Democrats talk of a creeping authoritarianism unchecked by Congress. A near-permanent state of gridlock threatens to diminish American democracy itself.
articles.abstract: Republicans warn of a dark plot to overthrow the Trump government and Democrats talk of a creeping authoritarianism unchecked by Congress. A near-permanent state of gridlock threatens to diminish American democracy itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers recover from a dispiriting government shutdown and prepare for President Trump’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, Capitol Hill is absorbed with concern that Mr. Trump’s presidency has pushed an already dysfunctional Congress into a near-permanent state of gridlock that threatens to diminish American democracy itself.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: In Nassar Case, Michigan State Wanted Famed Ex-Prosecutor to Both Examine and Defend It
articles.snippet: Patrick J. Fitzgerald said he found no evidence university employees knew the doctor was molesting patients. Critics say his review was tainted.
articles.abstract: Patrick J. Fitzgerald said he found no evidence university employees knew the doctor was molesting patients. Critics say his review was tainted.
articles.lead_paragraph: As sexual abuse reports against Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar flooded in a year ago, besieged officials at Michigan State University announced they had ordered an internal review. Overseeing it would be Patrick J. Fitzgerald, a former federal prosecutor whose reputation for investigations into mobsters, terrorists and corrupt politicians led admirers to deem him a modern-day Eliot Ness.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Oil Boom Gives the U.S. a New Edge in Energy and Diplomacy
articles.snippet: Having survived a slump, shale drilling is surging as prices recover, limiting market upheaval and providing Washington with strategic leeway.
articles.abstract: Having survived a slump, shale drilling is surging as prices recover, limiting market upheaval and providing Washington with strategic leeway.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A substantial rise in oil prices in recent months has led to a resurgence in American oil production, enabling the country to challenge the dominance of Saudi Arabia and dampen price pressures at the pump.

articles.headline: How Amazon Benefits From Losing Cities’ HQ2 Bids
articles.snippet: The applications from 238 places contained valuable information, like potential tax breaks, that the company can use for other projects.
articles.abstract: The applications from 238 places contained valuable information, like potential tax breaks, that the company can use for other projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The other week, 218 cities and states lost in the sweepstakes to be the home of Amazon’s second headquarters, failing to make the list of 20 finalists.

articles.headline: Indian Slavery Once Thrived in New Mexico. Latinos Are Finding Family Ties to It.
articles.snippet: The revelations have not only prompted personal reckonings but also fueled a larger debate on Hispanic and Native American identity.
articles.abstract: The revelations have not only prompted personal reckonings but also fueled a larger debate on Hispanic and Native American identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Lenny Trujillo made a startling discovery when he began researching his descent from one of New Mexico’s pioneering Hispanic families: One of his ancestors was a slave.

articles.headline: Tech Giants Brace for Europe’s New Data Privacy Rules
articles.snippet: A stringent set of data protection rules will take effect in Europe in May. Facebook, Google and others are working overtime to be ready.
articles.abstract: A stringent set of data protection rules will take effect in Europe in May. Facebook, Google and others are working overtime to be ready.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past two months, Google has started letting people around the world choose what data they want to share with its various products, including Gmail and Google Docs.

articles.headline: How the Finance Industry Is Trying to Cash In on #MeToo
articles.snippet: Small financial firms, backed by hedge funds, are angling for business from sexual harassment victims. The industry has a checkered history.
articles.abstract: Small financial firms, backed by hedge funds, are angling for business from sexual harassment victims. The industry has a checkered history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Accusations of sexual harassment have felled dozens of executives, but in one quiet corner of the financial world, the #MeToo movement looks like a golden opportunity.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Olympic Dreams of a United Korea? Many in South Say, ‘No, Thanks’
articles.snippet: Young Koreans are more focused on domestic issues, like unemployment and whether they can live as well as their parents did, than a costly and complex reunification.
articles.abstract: Young Koreans are more focused on domestic issues, like unemployment and whether they can live as well as their parents did, than a costly and complex reunification.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The last time South Korea hosted an Olympics, in 1988, the North not only refused to take part, it blew up a South Korean airliner 10 months before the Games. Yet South Koreans at the time expressed hope that the two Koreas, divided by the Cold War, could one day become a single nation again.

articles.headline: Chinese Investors Keep Losing Billions Online. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: The country’s latest $5 billion flameout shows how smartphones and the rise of online finance lure unsophisticated investors hoping for high returns.
articles.abstract: The country’s latest $5 billion flameout shows how smartphones and the rise of online finance lure unsophisticated investors hoping for high returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The company’s name appeared in ads for the local marathon. Its logo was emblazoned on the jerseys of two professional soccer teams in Spain. Its founder had been lauded by the government’s official television channel.
